text: I lowered my voice and pressed on, “Where exactly is this? Why do you seem so familiar with it?”
Alicia didn’t answer immediately. She turned the token in her palm, as if weighing whether to let the words out.
“Because I’ve been here before.”
“Once?”
She drew a soft breath. “More than once.”
The fading glow of the basement reflected in her eyes like a thread about to snap. Her shoulders loosened for a brief second, then tensed again.
“That’s why you’re so practiced.”
“Mm.”
“Then when you said ‘we’ll need it tomorrow’—you’re coming back?”
“They’ll leave traces.”
“I need to confirm whether this time it’s ‘earlier.’”
She spoke plainly, but stopped at just enough of an answer—deliberately avoiding a deeper truth.
Lucia cut in softly, “Mentor… please stop pushing yourself, okay? You don’t look well.”
“I’m fine.”
“You always say that.”
Lucia pulled the cloak tighter around her shoulders, the motion so practiced it was clear she’d done this many times before.
At last, she shifted her gaze away from the formation and looked at me. “Let’s go back.”
“You shouldn’t have come out tonight… but since you did, consider yourself ‘lucky.’”
“Lucky?”
“You weren’t pulled in any deeper.”
She turned and walked toward the exit. Her steps were steady—but like steadiness forced out of the last breath she had.
At the edge of the formation lay an unremarkable gray fragment of stone. When I picked it up, a faint tremor pulsed through my fingertips.
“…That stone wasn’t here just now.”
Fine etched marks surfaced across the stone’s surface, as if traced over countless times.
